subject: History
title: Trepanation: Drilling Into Skulls
description: Learn Trepanation: Drilling Into Skulls in one minute.

hook.text: The oldest known surgical procedure involved drilling a hole in a living person's skull. Many patients survived.

buildup.text: Trepanation dates back 7,000 years. Skulls from Peru, France, and Africa show carefully drilled openings.

discovery.text: Bone regrowth around many holes proves patients lived weeks, months, or even years after the procedure.

twist.text: Why they did it remains debatedâ€”treating head injuries, epilepsy, or releasing evil spirits. Maybe all three.

climax.text: Modern neurosurgery still drills holes in skulls to relieve pressure. The technique is ancient; the tools changed.

punchline.text: Stone Age surgeons invented brain surgery.

quiz.question: How do we know trepanation patients often survived the procedure?
options: Ancient texts describe their recovery stories
Bone regrowth around the holes proves long-term survival
Nearby graves contained healing herbs and bandages
